Package org.wmn4j.mir

Interface Pattern

All Superinterfaces:
Iterable<Durational>
public interface Pattern extends Iterable<Durational>
Interface for musical patterns. The patterns can represent motifs, melodies, or segments of polyphonic music. A pattern is a sequence of notes, chords, and rests. A pattern can be monophonic or polyphonic. In a monophonic pattern there are no simultaneously occurring notes or chords. In a polyphonic pattern there can be multiple notes occurring at the same time in chords or in multiple voices.

The notation elements in monophonic pattern are iterated in temporal orders. For polyphonic patterns the elements are iterated first by iterating through the voice with the smallest number and then moving on the voice with the next greatest number and so on.

Implementations of this interface are required to be thread-safe.

    • getVoice

      Iterable<Durational> getVoice(int voiceNumber)
      Returns the contents of the voice with the given number. The contents of the voice are iterated in their temporal order, i.e., from left to right int notation.
      Parameters:
      voiceNumber - the number of the voice whose contents are returned
      Returns:
      the contents of the voice with the given number

    • equalsInPitch

      boolean equalsInPitch(Pattern other)
      Returns true if this pattern contains the same pitches in the same order as other, otherwise returns false. The pitches must be spelled the same way for the patterns to be considered equal in pitch. Rhythm is ignored.
      Parameters:
      other - the pattern against which this is compared for pitch equality.
      Returns:
      true if this pattern contains the same pitches in the same order as other, otherwise returns false

    • equalsEnharmonically

      boolean equalsEnharmonically(Pattern other)
      Returns true if this pattern contains the enharmonically same pitches in the same order as other, otherwise returns false. The pitch spellings are not considered, but they are compared using enharmonic equality. Rhythm is ignored.
      Parameters:
      other - the pattern against which this is compared for enharmonic pitch equality.
      Returns:
      true if this pattern contains the enharmonically same pitches in the same order as other, otherwise returns false

    • equalsTranspositionally

      boolean equalsTranspositionally(Pattern other)
      Returns true if this pattern can be transposed chromatically so that its pitches are enharmonically equal to those of other, otherwise returns false. Durations are not considered in the comparison.
      Parameters:
      other - the pattern against which this is compared for transposed enharmonic pitch equality.
      Returns:
      true if this pattern can be transposed chromatically so that its pitches are enharmonically equal to those of other, otherwise returns false

    • equalsInDurations

      boolean equalsInDurations(Pattern other)
      Returns true if this pattern has the same durations as the other pattern. The durations of notes in this pattern must match the durations of notes in the given pattern and the durations of rests in this must match the durations of the rests in the given pattern. Pitches are ignored.
      Parameters:
      other - the pattern against which this is compared for durational equality
      Returns:
      true if this pattern has the same durations as the other pattern

    • size

      int size()
      Returns the number of durational notation elements in this pattern.
      Returns:
      the number of durational notation elements in this pattern
